section.title: Secondary Diminished Chords
section.p: The chord has dominant function. Since chords of dominant function typically resolve to chords of tonic function, diminished triads as well as halfdiminished and fullydiminished seventh chords occur as secondary diminished chordssecondary diminished chords.

Minor triads are tonicized by fully diminished seventh chords. Major triads are traditionally tonicized by half diminished seventh chords but can also be tonicized by fully diminished seventh chords.

section.title: Analyzing Secondary Diminished Chords
section.p: When you encounter a chord with a chromaticism and suspect it is a secondary diminished seventh chord, use the following process.

li.p: Stack the chord in thirds to determine the root and quality. If the chord quality is diminished (if a triad) or a halfdiminished and fullydiminished seventh chord, go on to step 2. If the chord quality is not a diminished triad or a halfdiminished and fullydiminished seventh chord, the chord is not a secondary diminished chord.
The chord in question is an F major triad in first inversion.

Determine the note that would be a minor 2nd above the root of the chord you are analyzing. If this note would be the root of a diatonic chord, the chord you are analyzing is a secondary diminished chord.

section.title: Writing Secondary Diminished Chords
section.p: To write a secondary diminished chord, use the following procedure.

li.p: First determine the note that is the root of the chord being tonicized (the chord to the right of the slash).
Determine in the key of C minor (C is the root of the chord, which is the Roman numeral after the slash): B is the root of in C minor because it is a m2 below C.
Build a fullydiminished seventh chord on B: BDFA
Invert the chord accordingly. inversion means the 7th of the chord (A) is the bass note.
